title: How to Draw Super Mario

steps.headline: Draw a pear shaped head with two ear outlines.
Add a curved line joining the ear-heads and another small one over it for the cap line with a single sideburn and a round nose.
Draw ovals to depict the eyes with inner ovals for the eyeballs as well.
steps.description: Draw tiny curved lines over the eyes for the eyebrows. Draw a curved rectangle for the moustache overlapping the nose and a curved line joining the moustache for the mouth.

steps.headline: Add a circle to form the chest and belly area of the character.
Join two overlapping angular rectangles to the bottom of the circle for the legs.
Join another rectangle with a curved end for the right hand and two adhered rounded rectangles for the left hand of the character.
steps.description: Draw overlapping ovals on the wrist areas and irregular ovals for the shoes.

steps.headline: Give hands to the Mario by sketching two different shapes for his hands.
Give Mario shoulder straps by drawing two curved overlapping rectangles.
Now use the guide stokes to neatly draw clean lines with necessary curves and details such as drawing the ‘M’, fingers and glove details, trouser-folds and shoe-heels.
The drawing is over.
steps.description: Clean all guides and extra, unnecessary lines.

steps.headline: Draw a circle for Mario's head.
steps.description: Add two perpendicular guidelines to help position the eyes and nose overlapping the head.

steps.headline: Roughly sketch out his hat, keeping in mind that this covers his entire forehead.
Draw two smaller ovals, one for each eye.
steps.description: These are a bit flatter on the bottom than on the other sides, sort of like a very rounded, very tall semicircles. Inside each eye draw two ovals, one inside the other, near the inside edge of his eyes. Add the eyebrows, two crescent-shapes, directly below the hat.

steps.headline: Draw Mario's nose.
steps.description: Depending on the angle, this is usually just a large circle meets the bottom of his eyes. Sketch out his mustache directly below his nose. It's made up of two lines parallel to the flattish bottom of his eyes, both ending a little past the end of his eyebrows, and a curve connecting the ends of them. For now, this should look like a crude D that's tipped over.

steps.headline: Draw a circle slightly larger than the head for the body.
steps.description: Depending on the angle, this may need to be more of a pear shape. Draw the arm and leg shapes. These are all about the same length as his head, hat included, and get just a little wider at the end farthest from his body. Sketch the hands and feet. The hands are just circles, while the feet are a cross between ovals and beans-they are perfectly round on the inside and bean-shaped on the outside.

steps.headline: Draw the details.
steps.description: Give Mario some fingers and his shoes some soles (if you can see them). Draw the bumps on the bottom of his mustache and clarify his hat some. Finish this step by adding details to his clothes. Don't forget the M on Mario's hat! Review your drawing. Now is the time to fix up any mistakes. When you're satisfied, clean up the lines you don't want.

steps.headline: Color Mario, lightly erasing all of your lines beforehand (but making sure they're still slightly visible).
steps.description: This helps ensure that they aren't visible afterwards.Mario is now ready for action!

text: Simple Mario Character Draw a pear shaped head with two ear outlines.  Add a curved line joining the ear-heads and another small one over it for the cap line with a single sideburn and a round nose.  Draw ovals to depict the eyes with inner ovals for the eyeballs as well. Draw tiny curved lines over the eyes for the eyebrows. Draw a curved rectangle for the moustache overlapping the nose and a curved line joining the moustache for the mouth. Add a circle to form the chest and belly area of the character.  Join two overlapping angular rectangles to the bottom of the circle for the legs.  Join another rectangle with a curved end for the right hand and two adhered rounded rectangles for the left hand of the character. Draw overlapping ovals on the wrist areas and irregular ovals for the shoes. Give hands to the Mario by sketching two different shapes for his hands.  Give Mario shoulder straps by drawing two curved overlapping rectangles.  Erase all overlapping strokes.  Now use the guide stokes to neatly draw clean lines with necessary curves and details such as drawing the ‘M’, fingers and glove details, trouser-folds and shoe-heels.  The drawing is over. Clean all guides and extra, unnecessary lines. Color and shade your drawing.  Graphic Super Mario Draw a circle for Mario's head. Add two perpendicular guidelines to help position the eyes and nose overlapping the head. Roughly sketch out his hat, keeping in mind that this covers his entire forehead.  Draw two smaller ovals, one for each eye. These are a bit flatter on the bottom than on the other sides, sort of like a very rounded, very tall semicircles. Inside each eye draw two ovals, one inside the other, near the inside edge of his eyes. Add the eyebrows, two crescent-shapes, directly below the hat. Draw Mario's nose. Depending on the angle, this is usually just a large circle meets the bottom of his eyes. Sketch out his mustache directly below his nose. It's made up of two lines parallel to the flattish bottom of his eyes, both ending a little past the end of his eyebrows, and a curve connecting the ends of them. For now, this should look like a crude D that's tipped over. Draw a circle slightly larger than the head for the body. Depending on the angle, this may need to be more of a pear shape. Draw the arm and leg shapes. These are all about the same length as his head, hat included, and get just a little wider at the end farthest from his body. Sketch the hands and feet. The hands are just circles, while the feet are a cross between ovals and beans-they are perfectly round on the inside and bean-shaped on the outside. Draw the details. Give Mario some fingers and his shoes some soles (if you can see them). Draw the bumps on the bottom of his mustache and clarify his hat some. Finish this step by adding details to his clothes. Don't forget the M on Mario's hat! Review your drawing. Now is the time to fix up any mistakes. When you're satisfied, clean up the lines you don't want. Color Mario, lightly erasing all of your lines beforehand (but making sure they're still slightly visible). This helps ensure that they aren't visible afterwards.Mario is now ready for action!
